TOPIC_DESCRIPTION:
Economic activity relates to whether or not a person who was aged 16 to 74 was working or looking for work in the week before census. Rather than a simple indicator of whether or not someone was currently in employment, it provides a measure of whether or not a person was an active participant in the labour market.
A person's economic activity is derived from their 'activity last week'. This is an indicator of their status or availability for employment - whether employed, unemployed, or their status if not employed and not seeking employment. Additional information included in the economic activity classification is also derived from information about the number of hours a person works and their type of employment - whether employed or self-employed.
The census concept of economic activity is compatible with the standard for economic status defined by the International Labour Organisation (ILO). It is one of a number of definitions used internationally to produce accurate and comparable statistics on employment
The unit is for a particular count (e.g. people or households)

Age is derived from the date of birth question and is a person's age at their last birthday, at 27 March 2011. Dates of birth that imply an age over 115 are treated as invalid and the person's age is imputed. Infants less than one year old are classified as 0 years of age.

Country of birth is the country in which a person was born. The country of birth question included six tick-box responses: one for each of the four parts of the UK (England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland); one for the Republic of Ireland; and one for 'Elsewhere'.
Where a person ticked 'Elsewhere', they were asked to write in the current name of the country in which they were born. Responses are assigned codes based on the National Statistics Country Classification.

CDU_FIELD_NAME: The grouping of countries within the classification is broadly regional
CENSUS_CELLNAME: but takes into account the grouping of European Union (EU) countries. Countries in the EU are grouped into those that were EU members in March 2001
TOPIC: and those that became members (accession countries) between April 2001 and March 2011 as part of the EU enlargement process.

CDU_FIELD_NAME: When a person's written response to the country of birth question was a former country name
CENSUS_CELLNAME: and the country that it relates to no longer exists and is not wholly contained within the geographic boundary of a current country
TOPIC: the response was coded to one of the additional categories contained in the 'Former country' grouping. For example

Where a person ticked 'Elsewhere', they were asked to write in the current name of the country in which they were born. Responses are assigned codes based on the National Statistics Country Classification.

CENSUS_CELLNAME: but takes into account the grouping of European Union (EU) countries. Countries in the EU are grouped into those that were EU members in March 2001
TOPIC: and those that became members (accession countries) between April 2001 and March 2011 as part of the EU enlargement process.

CDU_FIELD_NAME: When a person's written response to the country of birth question was a former country name

TOPIC: the response was coded to one of the additional categories contained in the 'Former country' grouping. For example

TOPIC_DESCRIPTION: Age is derived from the date of birth question and is a person's age at their last birthday, at 27 March 2011. Dates of birth that imply an age over 115 are treated as invalid and the person's age is imputed. Infants less than one year old are classified as 0 years of age.

TOPIC_DESCRIPTION: The unit is for a particular count (e.g. people or households)

Economic activity relates to whether or not a person who was aged 16 to 74 was working or looking for work in the week before census. Rather than a simple indicator of whether or not someone was currently in employment, it provides a measure of whether or not a person was an active participant in the labour market.
A person's economic activity is derived from their 'activity last week'. This is an indicator of their status or availability for employment - whether employed, unemployed, or their status if not employed and not seeking employment. Additional information included in the economic activity classification is also derived from information about the number of hours a person works and their type of employment - whether employed or self-employed.
The census concept of economic activity is compatible with the standard for economic status defined by the International Labour Organisation (ILO). It is one of a number of definitions used internationally to produce accurate and comparable statistics on employment

Country of birth is the country in which a person was born. The country of birth question included six tick-box responses: one for each of the four parts of the UK (England, Wales, Scotland and Northern Ireland); one for the Republic of Ireland; and one for 'Elsewhere'.
Where a person ticked 'Elsewhere', they were asked to write in the current name of the country in which they were born. Responses are assigned codes based on the National Statistics Country Classification.

CDU_FIELD_NAME: The grouping of countries within the classification is broadly regional
CENSUS_CELLNAME: but takes into account the grouping of European Union (EU) countries. Countries in the EU are grouped into those that were EU members in March 2001
TOPIC: and those that became members (accession countries) between April 2001 and March 2011 as part of the EU enlargement process.

CDU_FIELD_NAME: When a person's written response to the country of birth question was a former country name
CENSUS_CELLNAME: and the country that it relates to no longer exists and is not wholly contained within the geographic boundary of a current country
TOPIC: the response was coded to one of the additional categories contained in the 'Former country' grouping. For example

TOPIC_DESCRIPTION: Age is derived from the date of birth question and is a person's age at their last birthday, at 27 March 2011. Dates of birth that imply an age over 115 are treated as invalid and the person's age is imputed. Infants less than one year old are classified as 0 years of age.

Economic activity relates to whether or not a person who was aged 16 to 74 was working or looking for work in the week before census. Rather than a simple indicator of whether or not someone was currently in employment, it provides a measure of whether or not a person was an active participant in the labour market.
A person's economic activity is derived from their 'activity last week'. This is an indicator of their status or availability for employment - whether employed, unemployed, or their status if not employed and not seeking employment. Additional information included in the economic activity classification is also derived from information about the number of hours a person works and their type of employment - whether employed or self-employed.
The census concept of economic activity is compatible with the standard for economic status defined by the International Labour Organisation (ILO). It is one of a number of definitions used internationally to produce accurate and comparable statistics on employment
The unit is for a particular count (e.g. people or households)
